background: A farmer has a certain amount of land to process hay using either a windrower or a hay harvester. Each machine processes a different amount of hay, produces a certain amount of methane gas, and requires a certain amount of fuel per acre.
constraints: Number of acres processed by the windrower is a non-negative integer
Number of acres processed by the hay harvester is a non-negative integer
Total acres processed by both machines cannot exceed TotalAcres
Total fuel used by both machines cannot exceed TotalFuel
Total methane produced by both machines cannot exceed MaxMethane
MethaneWindrower * acres processed by the windrower + MethaneHarvester * acres processed by the hay harvester <= MaxMethane
FuelWindrower * acres processed by the windrower + FuelHarvester * acres processed by the hay harvester <= TotalFuel
objective: Maximize the total amount of hay processed
description: A farmer has \(\var{TotalAcres}\) acres of land on which he must process hay using either a windrower or hay harvester. For each acre of land, the windrower can process \(\var{HayWindrower}\) kg of hay while the hay harvester can process \(\var{HayHarvester}\) kg of hay. Per acre, the windrower produces \(\var{MethaneWindrower}\) kg of methane gas and requires \(\var{FuelWindrower}\) kg of fuel. On the other hand, the hay harvester produces \(\var{MethaneHarvester}\) kg of methane gas per acre and requires \(\var{FuelHarvester}\) kg of fuel. There are \(\var{TotalFuel}\) kg of fuel available and the farmer can produce at most \(\var{MaxMethane}\) kg of methane gas. For how many acres should each machine be used to maximize the amount of hay processed?

parameters.definition: Total acres of available land for hay processing
Hay processed by the windrower per acre
Hay processed by the hay harvester per acre
Methane gas produced by the windrower per acre
Fuel required by the windrower per acre
Methane gas produced by the hay harvester per acre
Fuel required by the hay harvester per acre
